results.title: Nature & nurture interwoven
results.creator_credit: Darrel Schwandt, George A. Colburn, GPN and DLGHS
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
Research in behaviour genetics, the concept of inheritability and data from twin studies are juxtaposed with observations about how parents change the future by changing the circumstances of children’s lives. Observes urban Brazilian children meeting their country cousins in the context of the nature versus nurture debate.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Darrel Schwandt, George A. Colburn, GPN and DLGHS

results.title: Prenatal development & the birth process
results.creator_credit: Darrel Schwandt and George A. Colburn
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
Examines research on the prenatal period, as well as neonatal starting dates that facilitate an infant’s survival. Alternative birth processes are analysed. Families in Brazil, Russia and the U.S. prepare for birth and go through delivery. Human genetics principles, prenatal care and risk factors are considered.

results.title: The Ecology of development
results.creator_credit: Darrel Schwandt, George A. Colburn, GPN and DLGHS
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
Factors such as biological inheritance, temperament, caregiving, family, peers, schooling, culture and history are introduced. Four levels of the environment are defined and illustrated: microsystem, mesosystem, exosystem and macrosystem. We meet twelve families from five countries whose lives we share throughout the series.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Darrel Schwandt, George A. Colburn, GPN and DLGHS

results.title: Development & diversity
results.creator_credit: Darrel Schwandt, George A. Colburn, GPN and DLGHS
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Worlds of childhood”.
Exploration of the historical, cultural, and individual diversity of childhood: what development is, how it occurs and the significance of the the prolonged period of human infancy and childhood. A visual tour of development includes children in Russia, Japan, Brazil, Cameroon and New York.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 04. The Age of Iron
results.creator_credit: Taylor Downing, Bricomin Films, Channel Four, Goldcrest and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
The age of iron (2,000 BC - AD 200) conjures images of a truly epic story. Iron became an increasingly important element of an industry which has lasted almost to the present day. Iron was first discovered by India, later by China and Africa, and has been the sinew of industry until steel, electricity and oil took over. This program shows the different techniques used for smelting iron, 3500 years ago until the present. Iron was the turning point in history industrially and in many other areas. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 25. World in Conflict
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Channel Four, Bricomin Films, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 25 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
From the 1930’s depression came the rise of political leaders/ radicals. One such person was Adolf Hitler, who created a re-armed Germany. With this power Hitler conquered countries, including Poland. Britain and France declared war on Germany, and Japan bombed Pearl Harbour. America, Britain and Russia became allies - their strategy was firstly to fight Germany and then to fight Japan. The war period saw the creation of military machines and the invention of the atomic bomb, which was later to be used on Japan.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 05. Greece and Rome
results.creator_credit: Taylor Downing, Nicholas Barton, Channel Four, Bricomin Films, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
Greece and Rome (1,200 BC - AD 200). Civilisation came late to Europe but the ancient worlds of Greece and Rome established traditions that we still follow today. Greece brought us democracy, government by the people for the people, as well as the first great philosophers, scientists, and mathematicians. Rome, slower to develop than Greece, inherited Greece’s Hellenistic ideals. It had a great military power, and with Julius Caesar as its Emperor, controlled vast areas of Europe and Asia. Rome gave us the Latin language, and developed a legal system which provided the basis of Western law. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 05. The World Religions
results.creator_credit: Taylor Downing, Nicholas Barton, Channel Four, Bricomin Films, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
600 BC - AD 500 was a time when early humans believed that the natural world was one of spirits, and these were later to be replaced by Gods. Early religion was restricted to local cults, with individual tribes and groups worshipping their own gods. Hinduism developed, and is today the religion of 400 million Indians. Buddhism emerged within the context of Hinduism, and was later to become one of the greatest missionary religions which spread rapidly to different parts of the world.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 26. The Modern World
results.creator_credit: John Selwyn Gilbert, Channel Four, Bricomin Films, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 26 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This is the final episode of the series that covers the history of man’s progress in the world, from the very beginning of human origins through to the world we know today. This episode covers the major historical events that occurred in world history over the period from 1945 to the present - including the introduction of Atomic bombs; the Vietnam conflicts; and the emergence of a Space Exploration program. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 15. Africa before the Europeans
results.creator_credit: David Wright, Nicholas Barton, Channel Four, Bricomin Films, Goldcrest TV and Network Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 15 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode covers the history of Africa over the period 100-1500AD. Before the 15th Century, Africa was a rich continent of civilisations and empires, and the Nile was the lifeblood of the people. By AD 1000, Islam had the whole of North Africa in its grasp. To the Europeans, Africa was known as “the Dark Continent”, and by the 18th century they were transporting people from Africa for the slave trade. Based on The Times atlas of world history.
results.title_for_label: The World: A Television History. Ep. 15. Africa before the Europeans
